app.title: Can I Eat The Mushroom? üçÑ
app.subtitle: Answer questions about the mushroom to determine if it's edible or poisonous.

image_upload.section_description: Upload a photo of the mushroom to automatically fill in visible attributes using AI vision.
image_upload.drag_and_drop: Drag and drop or click to upload
image_upload.fill_remaining: Please fill in the remaining questions below to get your result.

question_form.ai_suggestion_available: AI suggestion available for this question

result.title: üçÑ Result
result.unknown: Could not determine if this mushroom is safe.

odor.question: What is the odor of the mushroom?
odor.description: How the mushroom smells: like almond/anise (licorice‚Äëlike), tar/chemical, fishy, foul, musty, no smell, sharp/pungent, or spicy. Example: Some edible Agaricus smell pleasantly like almond or anise; some poisonous ones smell foul or sharply pungent.

gill_color.question: What is the gill color?
gill_color.description: The color of the gills underneath the cap. Example: Agaricus gills often start pink and turn chocolate‚Äëbrown as they mature.

spore_print_color.question: What is the spore print color?
spore_print_color.description: If you lay the cap gills‚Äëdown on paper, the spores leave a colored 'print' (black, brown, chocolate, white, yellow, etc.). Example: Agaricus typically have a chocolate‚Äëbrown spore print; many Russula have white prints.

stalk_color_below_ring.question: What is the stalk color below the ring?
stalk_color_below_ring.description: The color of the stalk below the ring. Example: A stalk can be white above the ring and brown below it.

stalk_color_above_ring.question: What is the stalk color above the ring?
stalk_color_above_ring.description: The color of the stalk above the ring. Example: A white upper stalk stays white; some species have yellowish tint above the ring.

stalk_root.question: What is the stalk root type?
stalk_root.description: What the very bottom of the stalk (in the ground) looks like: a bulb, a club shape, a cup, even width, root‚Äëlike strings, or a pointed 'root.' Sometimes it's unknown. Example: Some Amanita have a round bulb at the base.

population.question: What is the population?
population.description: How the mushrooms are growing in an area: very common, in clusters from one spot, lots, scattered around, several together, or single and alone. Example: A tight bunch from the same base is 'clustered'; one here and there is 'solitary.'

habitat.question: What is the habitat?
habitat.description: Where it's growing: lawns/grass, leaf litter, meadows, paths, city places, waste areas, or woods. Example: In a lawn is 'grass'; in a forest is 'woods.'

ring_type.question: What is the ring type?
ring_type.description: What the ring looks like: cobwebby, fades away, flares outward, large, none, hanging like a skirt, sheathing, or just a colored band. Example: A skirt‚Äëlike ring that hangs is 'pendant'; a simple band of color is a 'zone.'

ring_number.question: How many rings?
ring_number.description: How many rings are on the stalk: none, one, or two. Example: Store‚Äëbought Agaricus usually have one ring; some species have no ring

cap_shape.question: What is the cap shape?
cap_shape.description: What the top of the mushroom looks like from the side: like a bell, a cone, a dome, flat, with a little bump, or sunken in the middle. Example: A typical grocery button mushroom has a dome‚Äëshaped cap; a mature parasol can look flat.

cap_color.question: What is the cap color?
cap_color.description: The main color of the cap (e.g., brown, white, yellow, red, gray, pink, etc.). Example: Button mushroom caps are often white; many field mushrooms are brown

stalk_shape.question: What is the stalk shape?
stalk_shape.description: Whether the stalk gets wider toward the base or narrower toward the base. Example: A club‚Äëlike stalk that swells near the bottom is 'wider at base'; a stalk that thins toward the bottom is 'narrower at base.'

gill_spacing.question: What is the gill spacing?
gill_spacing.description: How tightly packed the gills are under the cap: close/crowded or more spaced out. Example: Store mushrooms usually have crowded gills; some wild ones have gills that are more widely spaced.
